solution: We may assume that one of the triangles is attached to side $\overline{AB}$. The second triangle can be attached to $\overline{BC}$ or $\overline{CD}$ to obtain two non-congruent figures. If the second triangle is attached to $\overline{AE}$ or to $\overline{DE}$, the figure can be reflected about the vertical axis of symmetry of the pentagon to obtain one of the two already counted. Thus the total is $\boxed{2}$.
model_solution:
We look at the two possible cases for the upper triangle (the two shown in the problem) and note that we can place the lower triangle in 2 ways in each of the cases.
Since the two triangles are congruent, we can rotate them by $72^{\circ}$ without changing the figure, so the placements of the triangles in the two cases are not all distinct, and we can remove the rotations that produce congruent figures.
